    Nation 















Hi everyone,
 
After the town of Greensburg,
  Kansas, was
  reduced to little more than rubble over the weekend, rescuers found a
  survivor in the wreckage today – bringing some good news to the grim
  story. Hari Sreenivasan will have our report on the aftermath from Greensburg.
 
When a disaster like this massive tornado strikes,
  the National Guard is often called upon to help citizens piece together
  broken lives. But during wartime, the guard can’t always be there in
  full force, David Martin will report. 
 
Reports said the tornado was more than a mile wide
  and it was a whopping F-5 storm – the classification for the very
  strongest twisters. What’s behind such a monster tornado? Cynthia
  Bowers will have the story from a storm prediction center in Norman, Oklahoma.
 
In business news, prices at the gas pump surged over
  the weekend, reaching $4.00 per gallon in some places. Anthony Mason will
  have the reasons behind the pump price spike.
 
Yesterday French voters elected Nicholas Sarkozy,
  the pro-American conservative candidate, in a close election that had a huge
  turnout. But would the French candidates’ personal lives horrify
  American voters? Jeff Greenfield will take a look at some of the culture
  behind France’s
  election.
 
And correspondent John Blackstone reports on what
  some are calling an agricultural emergency in the United States: the sudden
  disappearance of honeybees. The die-off has hit 27 states – and with
  about 30 percent of the nation’s food supply being pollinated by bees,
  the risk is great and scientists are scrambling to nail down the cause.
  We’ll have the story in a segment we’re calling Saving the World.
 
Finally, it was a day of much pomp and fanfare at
  the White House, as Queen Elizabeth II was welcomed to Washington. President Bush tonight is
  hosting the first white-tie dinner of his presidency in honor of the queen.
  Mark Phillips will share details of Elizabeth’s
  elegant day inside the beltway.
 
I hope you’ll join us.
 




Katie Couric
